title: RL33405
content: The House and Senate approved FY2007 defense appropriations and national defense authorization bills, with the President signing them into law. The appropriations bill includes $436.6 billion in new defense funding, while the authorization bill provides for operations abroad and other expenses. The FY2007 defense appropriations bill included $70 billion in additional appropriations as a "bridge fund" for operations abroad and other purposes, $4 billion below the Administration request. The Senate-passed bill provided $9 billion less than the request, allowing increases in non-defense appropriations while staying within the budget resolution cap. The conference agreement approved $70 billion in additional funds, $20 billion higher than originally provided. The FY2007 defense appropriations bill included $13.1 billion for Army and Marine Corps equipment repair and upgrades, $1.8 billion for border security, $700 million for counter drug operations in Afghanistan, $200 million for intelligence, $65 million for Predator UAVs, $20 million for peacekeepers in Sudan, and $175 million for wildfire suppression. The bill also provides over $17.1 billion for Army and $5.8 billion for Marine Corps reset costs, $100 million for Afghan counter-drug operations, and $200 million for wildfire suppression. The authorization conference agreement resolved key issues including altering DOD provisions for non-denominational prayer, promoting the head of the National Guard to four-star rank, and approving multiyear procurement of the F-22 fighter aircraft. It also expanded the President's authority to use the armed forces in domestic emergencies, allowed off-duty reservists to enroll in the TRICARE health insurance program, and provided expanded authority for the Defense Department to use funds for security assistance to foreign governments. The House and Senate have finalized agreements on the FY2007 defense appropriations bill and national defense authorization bill.
